entry.title: Ferguson mulls removing Brown shrine from middle of street
entry.summary: "The way we deal with this memorial is how we move forward in Ferguson, because that memorial represents the best and the worst of Ferguson."

entry.title: 2 separate shootings near Ferguson protests against police
entry.summary: A gas station was looted in Dellwood, near Ferguson.

entry.title: Police enforce curfew in Baltimore, disperse protesters
entry.summary:
The death of 25-year-old Freddie Gray has renewed a national debate on law enforcement and race that was sparked by police killing unarmed black men last year in Ferguson, Missouri; New York City and elsewhere.

Police in Ferguson, Missouri, were widely criticized last year for an aggressive, militarized response to demonstrations and rioting after a white police officer shot dead an unarmed black teenager.

entry.title: Activists seek probe of prosecutor's role in Ferguson case
Michael Brown's family sues Ferguson over shooting death
entry.summary: "We have not had a chance to read through (the lawsuit), but because it is pending litigation, the city won't be able to make any comment," Jeff Small, a spokesman for Ferguson, said in a telephone interview.

entry.title: Timeline of events after fatal police shooting in Ferguson
entry.summary:
AUG. 18 - Nixon calls the National Guard to Ferguson to help restore order and lifts the curfew.

AUG. 16 - Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon declares a state of emergency and imposes a curfew in Ferguson.

entry.title: Lawyer who sued after Ferguson wants special prosecutor in South Carolina man's shooting death
Surge in voter turnout gives blacks new voice in Ferguson, Missouri
entry.summary: The three candidates elected on Tuesday were Ella Jones, an African-American professor; Wesley Bell, an African-American judge; and former Ferguson mayor Brian Fletcher, who is white.

entry.title: Observers, new council members optimistic in Ferguson
entry.summary: James Harris walks into his polling place to vote Tuesday, April 7, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Observers, new council members optimistic in Ferguson
entry.summary:
Warren believes the change could fuel renewed political activism among blacks who live in Ferguson.

"The fact that we have a council that has three African-Americans - it's just wonderful, a new beginning for the city," said Fletcher, a former two-term mayor in Ferguson.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri elects two black city councillors
Race, reforms eyed as Ferguson, Missouri, voters head to polls
entry.summary: "This is a step we need to get the city headed in the right direction," said Patricia Bynes, a Democratic committeewoman for Ferguson Township who has been running a voter education program.

entry.title: Ferguson voters, black candidates to make history in council election
entry.summary:
Former Ferguson resident Tammy Hawkins, who is black and not related to candidate Adrienne Hawkins, said she has little faith in an election to change the city's character.

The civic unrest inspired Bob Hudgins, who is white, to challenge former Ferguson mayor Brian Fletcher for a seat representing Ward 2 on the council.

Voters in Ferguson, Missouri, go to the polls on Tuesday with an opportunity to transform the city's political fabric and put as many as three African Americans on the City Council for the first time in the city's history.

Protesters thronged the city, claiming Ferguson's majority-white police force harassed black residents while the city's white politicians did nothing.

entry.title: ACTU turns its back on Ferguson
Candidate's comparison of Fort Wayne to Ferguson draws heat
entry.summary: A candidate for mayor of Fort Wayne tried Wednesday to clarify his remarks comparing the city to Ferguson, Missouri, after the remarks drew criticism from a police union and former police chief.

entry.title: Trial set for videographer arrested covering Ferguson
entry.summary:
Freelance journalist Mary Moore poses for a portrait before entering Ferguson Municipal Court Tuesday, March 24, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

Moore was charged with municipal violations after an arrest on Oct. 3., while covering a demonstration outside Ferguson police headquarters.

(AP) - A video journalist arrested while covering the unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, after Michael Brown was fatally shot last summer plans to fight the charges at trial.

entry.title: Labor's Ferguson praises Baird's courage
entry.summary: Mr Ferguson even seemed to liken Mr Baird to former Labor prime minister Gough Whitlam.

entry.title: Part-Time Ferguson Mayor in Full-Time Spotlight
entry.summary:
After the shooting, Knowles and Police Chief Tom Jackson became the public face of Ferguson, holding news conferences, hosting public forums and reaching out to civil rights leaders and protesters.

Knowles has a full-time job: general manager of the state-contracted motor vehicle license office in Ferguson.

entry.title: Calm Prevails in Ferguson After Shooting of Police Officers
entry.summary: Two police officers were shot early Thursday morning in front of the Ferguson Police Department during a protest following the resignation of the city's police chief in the wake of damning U.S. Justice Department report.

entry.title: Obama: Racial bias in Ferguson police dept. not isolated
entry.summary:
In his most expansive comments yet about the Justice Department's report on bias against blacks in Ferguson, Obama said it was striking that investigators merely had to look at email sent by police officials to find evidence.

Ferguson city leaders are to meet with Justice Department officials in about two weeks to put forth an improvement plan.

entry.title: US finds racist, profit-driven practices in Ferguson
entry.summary:
At a brief news conference Wednesday, the mayor tried to show that Ferguson is serious about reform, saying the city has been working for some time to find more black officers.

"The chief has no credibility," said state Sen. Maria Chappelle-Nadal, a Democrat who represents Ferguson.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri police menaced African-American citizens for revenue, US federal investigation concludes
entry.summary:
RAW VIDEO: US probe finds systematic racial bias and unconstitutional policing targeting black people in Ferguson, Missouri, but clears white officer in the killing of Michael Brown.

Addressing reporters in Washington, DC, the Attorney General, Eric Holder, said many in Ferguson might be mistaken about the circumstances surrounding the shooting, but given the practices of the police and the city, he understood their anger and mistrust.

The report shows that 85 per cent of people subject to vehicle stops by Ferguson police were African-American; 90 percent of those who received citations were black; and 93 percent of people arrested were black.

A man is handcuffed and led away by a Missouri State Trooper during demonstrations in Ferguson, Missouri, in August 2014.

A police tactical team moves in to disperse protesters in Ferguson, Missouri, in August 2014.

entry.title: Eric Holder: Ferguson Police Created A 'Toxic' Environment
Feds: Evidence backs Ferguson officer's account in shooting
In Ferguson, scathing US report brings pressure for change
entry.summary:
In pairing the announcements, the Obama administration sought to offset community disappointment over the conclusion that the shooting of Michael Brown was legally justified with a message of hope for Ferguson's majority-black citizens.

"It is not difficult to imagine how a single tragic incident set off the city of Ferguson like a powder keg," Holder said.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III said the city had cooperated with the Justice Department and has made some changes, including a diversity training program for city employees.

Federal officials say they hope to avoid a court fight with Ferguson to force change.

entry.title: Barack Obama moves to demilitarise US cops after Baltimore and Ferguson protests
entry.summary: After controversy over the policing of high-profile protests in Baltimore, Maryland and Ferguson, Missouri, Obama said communities should not feel there is an "occupying force" in their neighbourhood.

entry.title: Beyonc? and Jay Z wired bail money to Baltimore and Ferguson protesters
entry.summary: 'When we needed money for bail for Baltimore protesters, I asked, hit Jay up, as I had for Ferguson [and he] wired tens of thousands' of dollars within mins.

entry.title: Few bills inspired by Michael Brown shooting, Ferguson unrest make it in Missouri Legislature
entry.summary: The Ferguson-related measure that came closest to passing would have limited police officers' use of deadly force in a way supporters said would comply with longstanding U.S. Supreme Court precedent.

entry.title: Missouri lawmakers pass on dozens of Ferguson-inspired bills
entry.summary:
(AP) - Missouri's legislative session began with hundreds of protesters shutting down the Senate, demanding changes to state law in response to the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a Ferguson police officer.

It ended Friday with the Senate again shut down - this time because of its own partisan divisions- and without action on a Ferguson-inspired bill that would have rewritten the laws police using deadly force.

Both the transfer and municipal court bills "were spurred out of concerns surrounding the events in Ferguson," said House Speaker Todd Richardson, R-Poplar Bluff.

entry.title: Second person injured following more gunfire in Ferguson: newspaper
entry.summary: Ferguson police declined to comment when reached by phone.

entry.title: Ferguson Horror: Men in truck 'randomly fire into crowd of protesters in Baltimore'
entry.summary: The Ferguson police department could not be immediately reached for comment.

entry.title: Report: 1 injured in gunfire at Ferguson protest
entry.summary: (AP) - A man has been injured by gunfire amid a protest in Ferguson, Missouri, and one person has been taken into custody, according to a newspaper report.

entry.title: Gallery: 42nd Annual Daytime Emmy Awards
entry.summary: Craig Ferguson poses in the pressroom with the at the award for outstanding game show host for iCelebrity Name Gamei 42nd annual Daytime Emmy Awards at Warner Bros.

entry.title: Ferguson police involved in a standoff after reports of shooting
entry.summary:
Ferguson police say a man shot his brother in the head and barricaded himself inside a home.

The home is in a residential area of Ferguson.

entry.title: Ferguson City Council Appoints Interim City Manager
entry.summary: Six Ferguson officials, including Shaw, have resigned or been fired since the report was released.

entry.title: Man indicted in Ferguson rally shooting that injured police
entry.summary: ST. LOUIS (AP) " A 20-year-old St. Louis man has been indicted on felony assault and weapons charges linked to a March shooting that wounded two police officers during a Ferguson protest.

entry.title: Ferguson saddened by walsh's exit

Ferguson shooting's witnesses denied bond-reduction request on charges of resisting arrest
Ferguson shooting's witness denied bond-reduction request
Court report raises conflict-of-interest concern in Ferguson
Court report raises conflict-of-interest concern in Ferguson
entry.summary: After the federal review, the Missouri Supreme Court in March appointed appeals Judge Roy Richter to take over the Ferguson court and asked court administration experts to take a look at how things were working.

entry.title: Missouri court report cites concerns about conflicts of interest in Ferguson's court system
entry.summary:
Ferguson Mayor James Knowles said Monday night that the court clerk staff had been placed under the police chief years ago because their offices are in the police building.

The report said Ferguson appears to have violated the Supreme Court's procedural rules by having police file a citation - and court staff open a file - before a prosecutor reviews the case.

entry.title: Court Report Raises Conflict-of-Interest Concern in Ferguson
entry.summary: The lines separating government powers have been blurred among Ferguson's court staff, police and prosecutor, raising concerns about potential conflicts of interest, according to a report released Monday by Missouri's judiciary.

entry.title: Ferguson Mulls Removing Michael Brown Shrine From Mid-Street
entry.summary:
To some, a makeshift shrine in the middle of the Ferguson street where Michael Brown was killed last summer is a hallowed symbol of a new civil rights movement over race and policing.

"It's a very sensitive topic," says Janie Jones, a black, Washington-based mediator who says she has been working behind the scenes with Ferguson municipal leaders and the Brown family on how to clear out the memorial without agitating the black community.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III, while appreciative of what the memorial's status as a nexus of protests and prayers, said it is now a public safety issue that comes with "any time you leave items in the middle of the roadway."

entry.title: Ferguson mulls replacing mid-street shrine to Michael Brown
entry.summary: (AP) - Leaders of the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, Missouri, are considering removing or replacing a makeshift shrine to Michael Brown that has lined the middle of the street where he was killed since last summer.

entry.title: Ferguson mulls replacing mid-street shrine to Michael Brown
Ferguson to pay attorney $1,335 an hour to pursue reforms
entry.summary: Brian Fletcher, a Ferguson council member elected in April, said the city faces a $2 million to $3 million budget deficit for the fiscal year ending June 30, and will likely face a similar deficit next year.

entry.title: Obama says inequality facing minority men behind unrest in Baltimore, Ferguson
Ferguson to pay attorney $1,335 an hour to pursue reforms
2 Ferguson stores burglarized during night of protests
entry.summary:
(AP) - Police in Ferguson are investigating burglaries of a discount store and a cellphone business near where protesters took to the streets for a second night.

Several dozen people marched down Ferguson's West Florissant Avenue on Wednesday night to protest the recent death of 25-year-old Freddie Gray while he was in Baltimore police custody.

entry.title: 2 Ferguson stores burglarized during night of protests

Latest on police-custody death: More protests in Ferguson
entry.summary: A Ferguson Police Department spokesman says three people were shot during protests Tuesday night and four police cars were damaged by rocks and chunks of asphalt thrown by demonstrators.

entry.title: Latest on police-custody death: More protests in Ferguson
entry.summary: Protesters have returned to Ferguson a day after looting, fires and gunfire broke out during demonstrations over the death of a black man who died of spinal injuries after his arrest by Baltimore police.

entry.title: Latest on Police-Custody Death: More Protests in Ferguson
entry.summary: Protesters Wednesday first rallied in Manhattan's Union Square, where they chanted "no justice, no peace" and "hands up, don't shoot," a reference to the police killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, last year.

entry.title: 3 shot during Ferguson protest; 5 arrested for looting
entry.summary: Protesters block the intersection of West Florissant Avenue and Canfield Drive in Ferguson, Mo., Tuesday night, April 28, 2015.

entry.title: Illinois teen admits to stealing guns to sell in Ferguson, Missouri
entry.summary: Moss and a juvenile accomplice stole the guns in order to sell them in Ferguson, prosecutors said.

entry.title: Illinois man admits gun thefts as part of alleged plot to arm Ferguson protesters
entry.summary: - A parolee admitted in court Wednesday that he helped steal assault-style rifles and other firearms from a store during what investigators say was his plot to sell them to protesters in Ferguson, Missouri.

entry.title: 2 separate shootings near Ferguson protests against police
entry.summary: In Ferguson, there were reports of two people being shot late Tuesday and early Wednesday, though it wasn't immediately clear if the shootings were linked to the protests.

entry.title: 2 people shot near protests in Ferguson related to death of man in Baltimore police custody
2 Separate Shootings Near Ferguson Protests Against Police
entry.summary: Gunshots, fires and looting rocked Ferguson overnight, as protests erupted following the death of a black man in police custody in Baltimore.

entry.title: Ferguson anarchists active in Baltimore to take advantage of Freddie Gray's death
Man who threatened Ferguson officer must stay off Facebook
entry.summary:
SEATTLE (AP) - A judge says a Washington state man who posted threatening comments on Facebook against a former Ferguson, Missouri, police officer can avoid prison but must stay off from social media sites.

But he says he accepted the argument that Abdul-Jabbaar's comments were simply a strong reaction to events in Ferguson, and he didn't intend to follow through on a threat to shoot Darren Wilson.

entry.title: Obama banters with Kimmel, reflects on Ferguson
entry.summary:
"What had been happening in Ferguson was oppressive and objectionable and was worthy of protest, but there was no excuse for criminal acts," he said.

During a more subdued segment, Obama reflected on Wednesday night's shooting of two police officers in racially tense Ferguson, Missouri, just days after he had delivered a speech on racial healing in Selma, Alabama.

entry.title: Ferguson manager is 5th out after DOJ report alleging bias
Ferguson cited for not submitting traffic-stop race data
entry.summary: Online biographies indicate that he grew up in north St. Louis County and lived in Ferguson before working for the city.

entry.title: Missouri appeals judge appointed to take over Ferguson court
entry.summary:
The Missouri Supreme Court said it is assigning state appeals Judge Roy L. Richter to hear all of Ferguson?s pending and future municipal court cases.

The Supreme Court said it also is assigning staff from the state court administrator?s office to aid Richter in reviewing Ferguson?s municipal court practices.

entry.title: US finds racist, profit-driven practices in Ferguson
entry.summary:
About 30 protesters braved sub-freezing weather Wednesday night to gather outside Ferguson's police station.

It also found Ferguson relies heavily on fines for petty offenses, such as jaywalking, to raise revenue.

entry.title: Giuliani blames Obama for Ferguson shootings, other unrest
entry.summary: Former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani (joo-lee-AH'-nee) says President Barack Obama is to blame for the police shootings in Ferguson, Missouri, and other disturbing events because he sets the tone for the nation.

entry.title: Obama banters with Kimmel, reflects on Ferguson
Ferguson police chief resigns
Ferguson judge named in DOJ report resigns
entry.summary: "Mr. Brockmeyer recognizes that the Department of Justice report, as well as recent media reports, regardless of their accuracy or validity, have diminished the public's confidence in the Ferguson Municipal Court."

entry.title: Robinson pleased with Ferguson progress
entry.summary:
Coach Trent Robinson believes Sydney Roosters centre Blake Ferguson is still some way from being back to his best but claims he will be a huge asset to his side later in the NRL season.

Ferguson crossed for two second-half tries in Monday's 20-12 win over Penrith - his first scores for the club in only his third game since ending his exile from the game following his sacking by Canberra in 2013.

Skipper Pearce said Ferguson's slotted in well with the rest of the squad since his arrival and his defensive efforts were more impressive than his two tries.

Ferguson spoke on Sunday about his desire to put his wild ways behind him and, with a child on the way, is fully aware of the consequences that will follow should he mess up off the field again.

entry.title: Activists Seek Probe of Prosecutor's Role in Ferguson Case
entry.summary: The hearing on Friday came a day after Brown's parents filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against the city of Ferguson, Wilson and Ferguson's former police chief.

entry.title: Michael Brown's family sues Ferguson over shooting death
entry.summary: The department's report did find racial bias and a pattern of illegal actions against African-Americans by the Ferguson Police Department.

entry.title: Michael Brown's family sues Ferguson over shooting death
entry.summary:
The civil lawsuit filed on Thursday listed incidents of alleged unlawful stops and arrests of African-Americans in Ferguson.

It asked for the court to assign a monitor to the city's police force for five years or until "the city of Ferguson has fully and effectually trained all of its police officers on the constitutional requirements of the use of deadly force."

entry.title: Michael Brown's family file wrongful death lawsuit against Ferguson, Mo.
entry.summary: Messages seeking comment from Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III, city spokesman Jeff Small and an attorney for Darren Wilson, the officer who shot Brown, were not immediately returned.

entry.title: Timeline of events after fatal police shooting in Ferguson
entry.summary: FILE - In this Friday, Nov. 28, 2014, file photo, police and Missouri National Guardsmen stand guard as protesters gather in front of the Ferguson Police Department, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Timeline of events after fatal police shooting in Ferguson
entry.summary: APRIL 22 -- Lawyers for Brown's family say they will file a civil lawsuit April 23 against the city of Ferguson.

entry.title: Timeline of events after fatal police shooting in Ferguson
entry.summary:
OCT. 21 - Nixon pledges to create an independent Ferguson Commission to examine race relations, failing schools and other broader social and economic issues in the aftermath of Brown's death.

He places the Ferguson Police Department in charge of security in Ferguson, with orders to work as a unified command with St. Louis city police and the Missouri Highway Patrol.

entry.title: Timeline of events after fatal police shooting in Ferguson
entry.summary:
AUG. 12 - Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson cancels plans to release the name of the officer who shot Brown, citing death threats against the police department and City Hall.

AUG. 19 - Nixon says he will not seek the removal of Ferguson prosecutor Bob McCulloch from the investigation into Brown's death.

AUG. 20 - Holder visits Ferguson to offer assurances about the investigation into Brown's death and to meet with investigators and Brown's family.

entry.title: Michael Brown's parents set to file wrongful death lawsuit against city of Ferguson
entry.summary: ST. LOUIS - Lawyers for the parents of an unarmed, black 18-year-old who was fatally shot by a white police officer in a St. Louis suburb say they plan to file a civil lawsuit Thursday against the city of Ferguson.

entry.title: Suspect charged in shooting of Ferguson, Missouri, police officers
entry.summary:
The Justice Department report said Ferguson police overwhelmingly arrested and issued traffic citations to black residents to boost city coffers through fines.

FERGUSON, Missouri - A 20-year-old man was charged on Sunday with first-degree assault in last week's shooting of two policemen during a protest rally in Ferguson, Missouri, a crime that shocked a city that has been devastated by months of racial strife.

The gunfire rang out just after midnight at the end of a rally to call for sweeping reforms in Ferguson, where an unarmed black 18-year-old was shot to death by a white officer last summer.

entry.title: Ferguson: suspect arrested in shooting of police officers
entry.summary: Clayton, Missouri: A 20-year-old man has been charged with first-degree assault in the shooting of two police officers in front of the Ferguson Police Department prosecuting attorney for St Louis County Robert McCulloch said..

entry.title: Standoff at Ferguson home ends peacefully, man in custody
entry.summary: A standoff involving Ferguson law enforcement officers and a man believed to have shot his brother in the head ended peacefully after hours of negotiations.

entry.title: Standoff at Ferguson home ends peacefully, man in custody
Standoff at Ferguson home ends peacefully, man in custody
entry.summary: Ferguson police spokesman Jeff Small says the suspect was taken into custody around 4:15 p.m. Tuesday.

entry.title: Standoff at Ferguson home after reports of shooting
entry.summary: (AP) - Tactical officers have surrounded a home in the St. Louis County town of Ferguson following reports of a shooting apparently involving two brothers.

entry.title: Ferguson shooting: no arrests yet as police continue hunt for gunman
entry.summary:
Ferguson: Nearly 48 hours after two officers were shot in racially charged Ferguson, Missouri, investigators had dozens of leads but no arrests to report in the hunt for the gunman.

One protester stood opposite the Ferguson police department with a sign "Cops Lives Matter," playing on the "Black Lives Matter" slogan that sprang up in the wake of the deaths of Mr Brown and an unarmed black man in New York City.

entry.title: Ferguson court clerk fired over racially charged emails insists she's not racist
entry.summary: Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III declined to discuss Twitty's firing, saying it's a personnel matter.

entry.title: Released Ferguson police emails likened welfare recipients to dogs
entry.summary: A protester wears tape over her mouth during a silent demonstration against what they say is police brutality after the Ferguson shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, by a white police officer, in March.

entry.title: 2 men accused of bomb plot during Ferguson protests
entry.summary: The indictment says the men were arrested in November, about a week before prosecutors announced they wouldn't charge the white Ferguson police officer who last summer fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown, who was black and unarmed.

entry.title: Man Accused in Ferguson Police Shooting Denied Lower Bond
entry.summary: A Missouri judge on Tuesday refused to reduce the bond of a 20-year-old man accused of shooting and wounding two police officers during a Ferguson protest, despite an attorney's insistence that the man was beaten by police into wrongly confessing.

entry.title: Ferguson wrong on privatisation: ALP MP
entry.summary: Labor heavyweight Martin Ferguson has heaped praise on conservative Premier Mike Baird and urged the ALP to reconsider its opposition to electricity privatisation should it lose the NSW election.

entry.title: Ferguson municipal court resumes with new judge
entry.summary:
Richter, who was also given the power to overhaul court practices in Ferguson, issued an order Wednesday barring cameras from the courtroom in response to heavy media interest.

It also faulted Ferguson for issuing an excessive number of arrest warrants when traffic-court offenders failed to pay their fines on time or missed court dates, with relatively minor violations then leading to jail time.

Local attorneys said they're optimistic that Richter's appointment will spur change not only in Ferguson's court system but also in the 80 other municipal courts spread across St. Louis County.

"I don't see any discernible difference," said Michael-John Voss of the Arch City Defenders, a nonprofit legal clinic that is suing Ferguson and the adjacent town of Jennings over their municipal court practices.

entry.title: Attorney for Ferguson suspect: Officers shot 'accidentally'
Ferguson police shooting suspect arrested, charged
entry.summary: - A 20-year-old man charged Sunday with shooting two police officers watching over a demonstration outside the Ferguson Police Department had attended a protest there earlier that night but told investigators he wasn't targeting the officers, authorities said.

entry.title: Surge in voter turnout gives blacks new voice in Ferguson, Missouri
entry.summary:
(Reuters) - A surge in voter turnout helped elect two new black city council members in Ferguson, a Missouri city found by the U.S. Justice Department to be rife with racial abuses in its police and court systems.

"Hopefully the new electeds will hold the city to a higher standard with regards to listening and acting on behalf of the under-represented," said state Representative Courtney Curtis, an African-American Ferguson resident.

entry.title: Surge in voter turnout gives blacks new voice in Ferguson, Missouri
Observers, newly elected council members optimistic after Ferguson election
entry.summary:
The percentage of elected blacks still falls short of the St. Louis suburb's racial makeup - two-thirds of Ferguson's 21,000 residents are black.

Saint Louis University political science professor Ken Warren said the turnout was particularly impressive because he had previously sensed a defeatist attitude among many black residents in Ferguson.

entry.title: Observers, new council members optimistic in Ferguson
entry.summary: More than 29 percent of Ferguson voters - double the percentage from the April 2014 election - went to the polls Tuesday and elected three new City Council members, including two blacks.

entry.title: Observers, new council members optimistic in Ferguson
Fired Ferguson clerk fired over emails says she's not racist
entry.summary: Ferguson's former municipal court clerk who was fired last month over racially charged emails linked to her says she's not a bigot and that she shared the messages as funny items she didn't consider offensive.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri voters select two black candidates for City Council
entry.summary: Ferguson has about 21,000 residents but has had only two black council members since its incorporation in 1894, including current Councilman Dwayne James, who was not up for re-election Tuesday.

entry.title: Ferguson election triples number of blacks on City Council
entry.summary: Bell is a lawyer and a criminology professor who had to defend himself because of a third job - municipal judge in a neighboring town of Velda City that, like Ferguson, derives a large percentage of its budget from municipal court fines.

entry.title: 2 black candidates elected to Ferguson City Council
Ferguson election could reshape City Council
entry.summary: Rich Baranowski, left, and Tracy Hardy vote in Ferguson's municipal election Tuesday, April 7, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Ferguson voters head to polls to reshape City Council
entry.summary: Voters braved heavy rain and lightning to get to the polls Tuesday for municipal elections in Ferguson, where the next city council will face the daunting task of remaking much of the beleaguered St. Louis suburb's leadership.

entry.title: In Ferguson, race and reform are on voters? minds in councillors? election today
entry.summary:
Three seats are up for election on the six-member City Council in Ferguson, where two-thirds of the residents are African-American and the municipal leadership has been long dominated by whites.

Community activists say a lack of adequate representation for African-Americans in Ferguson has contributed to a range of problems that were exposed when a white police officer killed an unarmed black teenager in August.

Ferguson was hit by months of protests including some violence and looting after white officer Darren Wilson fatally shot Michael Brown, 18, in a confrontation on Aug. 9.

entry.title: Ferguson voters go to polls to elect 3 City Council members
entry.summary: In this photo made in March 2015, Ferguson Ward 3 city council candidate Wesley Bell poses for a portrait in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Ferguson voters go to polls to elect 3 City Council members
entry.summary: The scrutiny of Ferguson after the shooting found that the town of 21,000 residents has a mostly white police force and city leadership - the mayor and five of the six council members are white - even though blacks make up about two-thirds of residents.

entry.title: Ferguson voters go to polls to elect 3 City Council members
entry.summary: (AP) - The next Ferguson City Council will face the daunting task of remaking much of the beleaguered town's leadership, a process that will begin soon after Tuesday's municipal election.

entry.title: FBI investigating 2 attacks with alleged Ferguson references
FBI investigating 2 attacks with alleged Ferguson references
entry.summary: Police said Street, who is white, shouted racial slurs and told Ford, who is black, "Go back to Ferguson."

entry.title: Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
entry.summary:
In this photo made Friday, April 3, 2015, Reginald Rounds, a volunteer with the Organization for Black Struggle, stops to check his map and voter rolls while canvassing a neighborhood in Ferguson, Mo.

In this photo made Friday, April 3, 2015, campaign literature sits on a table as volunteers prepare to canvass a neighborhood urging residents to vote in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Focus in Ferguson shifts to election of City Council members
entry.summary:
Ferguson staggers elections for three-year terms, so three council members and Mayor James Knowles III are not facing election this year.

"This election is about winning justice for residents of Ferguson," said Dan Cantor, national director of Working Families Party, which helped elect New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio last year.

Just 12.3 percent of Ferguson's registered voters went to the polls in April 2014, said Eric Fey, director of elections for St. Louis County.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri, releases racist emails from former officials
entry.summary:
The emails, although dating back years before the shooting, were among evidence presented by the Justice Department in a report in March that concluded that racism pervaded the Ferguson Police Department.

Ferguson Mayor James Knowles condemned the emails when the Justice Department report was released, saying, "These actions taken by these individuals are in no way representative of the employees of the city of Ferguson."

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri, releases racist emails from former officials
entry.summary: They were sent and received by Mary Ann Twitty, who was Ferguson's court clerk, as well as former Ferguson police Captain Rick Henke and former police Sergeant William Mudd.

entry.title: Ferguson, Missouri, releases racist emails from former officials
Ferguson releases racist emails from clerk to 2 officers
2 St. Louis men accused of plot to obtain bombs for use during Ferguson protests
entry.summary: ST. LOUIS - Two St. Louis men accused of planning to bomb protests in Ferguson, Missouri, have been indicted on federal charges.

entry.title: Mats Hummels 'gave his word' to Sir Alex Ferguson he WILL join Manchester United!?
Man accused in Ferguson police shooting to seek lower bond
entry.summary: (AP) - The attorney for a man accused of shooting two police officers during a Ferguson demonstration says he'll seek a lower bond for his client.

entry.title: 4 journalists arrested during last summer's Ferguson protests file federal suit against police
entry.summary: ST. LOUIS - Four journalists arrested during last summer's protests over the Ferguson shooting death of Michael Brown are suing St. Louis County's police department for civil rights violations and unlawful detention.

entry.title: No ill feelings toward Ferguson: Raiders
entry.summary:
While Nu'uausala might still hold strong connections with his old club, the same can't be said for Ferguson and the Raiders.

Ferguson spectacularly went AWOL from the Raiders in 2013 after a string of off-field indiscretions, leaving the club no choice but to sack the rising star just after he had played in a NSW State of Origin side.

entry.title: No ill feelings toward Ferguson: Raiders
entry.summary: Canberra skipper Jarrod Croker says there will be no hard feelings when he marks up on Sydney Roosters centre Blake Ferguson in the NRL match at Allianz Stadium on Sunday.

entry.title: Robinson says Ferguson's ready for Raiders
Robinson says Ferguson's ready for Raiders
entry.summary: Fresh from his two-try heroics against Penrith on Monday night, Ferguson confronts his past when he faces the Raiders for the first time since being sacked by the club in 2013.

entry.title: Robinson says Ferguson's ready for Raiders
entry.summary: Sydney Roosters coach Trent Robinson believes Blake Ferguson is mature enough to handle any extra attention that inevitably comes his way in Sunday's NRL showdown with Canberra.

entry.title: Settlement reached in lawsuit filed by Ferguson protesters
entry.summary: Three Missouri police agencies will restrict their use of tear gas and other chemical agents on crowds as part of a lawsuit settlement with six Ferguson protesters, according to court documents released Thursday.

entry.title: Settlement reached in lawsuit filed by Ferguson protesters
entry.summary: Protesters sued over the "unified command" that handled security at the protests sparked by the fatal police shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown in Ferguson in August.

entry.title: Candidate clarifies comparison of Fort Wayne to Ferguson
entry.summary:
A candidate for mayor of Fort Wayne is clarifying his remarks comparing that city to Ferguson, Missouri.

City Safety Director and former Police Chief Rusty York called any comparison between Fort Wayne and Ferguson "reckless and unfortunate."

entry.title: Lawyer: Police shooting suspect didn't fire gun in Ferguson
entry.summary:
ST. LOUIS (AP) - The man accused of shooting two police officers during a demonstration in Ferguson this month had nothing to do with the incident, his attorney said Wednesday, adding that police should be searching for the real shooter.

But a separate DOJ report found widespread racial bias in Ferguson's policing and in a municipal court system, which it said was driven by profit mostly extracted from black and low-income residents.

entry.title: Lawyer: Police shooting suspect didn't fire gun in Ferguson
entry.summary: Jeffrey L. Williams, 20, is accused of shooting and wounding the officers on March 12, during an early-morning rally sparked by the resignation of Ferguson's police chief.

entry.title: Ferguson City Council appoints interim city manager
entry.summary:
(AP) - The city of Ferguson, Missouri, has officially named an interim city manager to succeed the executive who resigned after a Justice Department report that found widespread racial bias in the police department.

KSDK-TV (http://on.ksdk.com/1FUcpdY ) reports the Ferguson City Council voted Tuesday night to appoint Pam Hylton to temporarily replace John Shaw.

entry.title: Trial set for videographer arrested covering Ferguson
entry.summary:
Moore is one of an estimated two dozen journalists from around the world and among the hundreds of people who've been arrested in Ferguson.

Missouri's online court reporting system does not show state charges against any of the arrested journalists, but Ferguson city charges would not appear there.

entry.title: Ferguson Facebook case part of debate about online threats
Ferguson municipal court resumes with new judge after DOJ report found problems with system
entry.summary:
Beck said an assistant Ferguson city prosecutor dismissed the ticket after she showed proof of insurance.

The federal report said Ferguson was counting on revenues from fines and fees to generate $3.1 million, or nearly one-quarter of its total $13.3 million budget for the 2015 fiscal year.

entry.title: Ferguson police shooting suspect returns to court
entry.summary:
Pro-police demonstrators wave to passing cars as they stand outside the Ferguson Police Department Sunday, March 15, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

About 100 pro-police demonstrators stand hold signs outside the Ferguson Police Department as the shadows of counter demonstrators are seen on the street Sunday, March 15, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

Protester Maldon Moffitt points his fingers and yells back at a pro-police demonstrator outside the Ferguson Police Department Sunday, March 15, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Ferguson officers 'not targeted'
entry.summary: "This wasn't any type of ambush shooting," Mr Christmas said, countering an earlier description by St Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar of the March 12 shooting outside Ferguson police headquarters.

entry.title: Man accused of shooting two Ferguson cops was 'beaten in custody': Lawyer claims police left him with welts on his face, neck, back and shoulders but stopped him taking photos of the injuries
entry.summary: The shooting of the officers followed a flurry of resignations and protests in the week after the U.S. JusticeDepartment released a damning report accusing Ferguson of racially biased policing.

entry.title: Attorney for Ferguson suspect: Officers shot 'accidentally'
entry.summary: (AP) - A man accused of shooting two police officers in Ferguson returned to court Tuesday over a claim that St. Louis County police used excessive force during his arrest.

entry.title: Ferguson police deny beating suspect
Attorney: Ferguson shooting suspect didn't target officers
entry.summary: (AP) - A man accused of shooting two officers last week in Ferguson was not targeting police or aiming at demonstrators at a late-night protest, his attorney said Monday as he countered an earlier police description of the crime.

entry.title: Authorities: Man accused of shooting officers in Ferguson says he was aiming for someone else
entry.summary: But Ferguson activist Derrick Robinson said Sunday that Williams told him during a jail visit that he had been robbed earlier on the day of the shooting and returned to the protest zone to retaliate.

entry.title: Man, 20, accused of shooting officers at Ferguson protest
entry.summary: People take part in a candlelight vigil Thursday, March 12, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Man, 20, charged with shooting 2 officers in Ferguson
entry.summary: But several activists who've been involved in the protests since the Aug. 9 fatal shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown by a Ferguson police officer told The Associated Press they were not familiar with Williams.

entry.title: Ferguson: suspect arrested in shooting of police officers
entry.summary: The shootings took place just hours after Ferguson's police chief resigned in the wake of a scathing US Justice Department report finding his force was rife with racial bias.

entry.title: Looted, burned Ferguson convenience store to be transformed into training center
entry.summary: FILE - This Monday, Aug. 11 2014 photo shows debris scattered in front of a QuikTrip store in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Part-time Ferguson mayor in full-time spotlight
entry.summary: But he was little known outside the area until Aug. 9, when Officer Darren Wilson shot 18-year-old Michael Brown and Ferguson found itself suddenly in the national spotlight.

entry.title: Part-time Ferguson mayor in full-time spotlight
entry.summary:
FILE - In this March 11, 2015 file photo, Ferguson Mayor James Knowles III announces the resignation of police chief Thomas Jackson during a news conference in Ferguson, Mo.

Despite calls for him to go, Knowles is the last man standing in Ferguson city government after a Justice Department report highly critical of the city's police force and court system prompted six officials to resign.

(AP) - In the days since the release of a Justice Department report that found widespread racial bias in the Ferguson Police Department, the mayor of the St. Louis suburb has become a part-time public servant in a full-time spotlight.

entry.title: Looted Ferguson Store to Be Transformed Into Training Center
entry.summary: A Ferguson convenience store that was looted and burned after the fatal shooting of Michael Brown will be rebuilt as a job training center.

entry.title: Calm prevails in Ferguson after shooting of police officers
entry.summary:
The protesters who spent eight months pressing for changes in Ferguson's police practices after the fatal shooting of Michael Brown take credit for this week's resignations of the city manager and the police chief.

Protesters gather across the street from the Ferguson Police Department, Thursday, March 12, 2015, in Ferguson, Mo.

entry.title: Calls for calm as the hunt continues for Ferguson shooter
entry.summary: Tensions have been high in Ferguson since August and escalated in November after a grand jury declined to prosecute officer Darren Wilson for Brown's killing.

entry.title: Shot Ferguson police officers released from US hospital
entry.summary: Police shine a light on a helmet as they investigate the scene where two police officers were shot outside the Ferguson Police Department.

entry.title: Obama to Jimmy Kimmel on Ferguson Shooters: ?There Are No Excuses for Criminal Acts? (Video)
entry.summary: "What had been happening in Ferguson was oppressive and objectionable and was worthy of protest," Obama said on ABC's "Jimmy Kimmel Live."

entry.title: Video captures exact moment two police officers were shot last night in Ferguson
entry.summary: The protest was a familiar scene in Ferguson, which saw similar and much larger demonstrations after the shooting death of black 18-year-old Michael Brown last summer by city police officer Darren Wilson.

entry.title: 2 officers shot at protest outside Ferguson police station
entry.summary: The shots were fired shortly after midnight as protesters gathered following the resignation of embattled Ferguson Police Chief Thomas Jackson on Wednesday.

entry.title: Ferguson removes top official after federal report highlights racial bias

entry.title: Ferguson city manager leaving in response to DOJ report

entry.title: Missouri Supreme Court Appoints New Judge to Oversee Ferguson
entry.summary: "Extraordinary action is warranted in Ferguson, but the Court also is examining reforms that are needed on a statewide basis."

entry.title: News24.com | Missouri judge appointed to take over Ferguson court
entry.summary: Ferguson Municipal Judge Ronald J Brockmeyer resigned on Monday, saying through a spokesperson that he was stepping down to promote public confidence in the court and help Ferguson "begin its healing process."

entry.title: Ferguson police chief stays on the job after federal report
entry.summary: Meanwhile, three Ferguson employees implicated in racist emails exposed by that report are now gone from their jobs, the mayor said.

entry.title: Ferguson police practices created 'oppressive and abusive' situation, Obama says
entry.summary: Ferguson Mayor James Knowles said three city workers who demonstrated "egregious racial bias" are no longer employed by the city, and said Ferguson officials are pursuing other reforms to try to reach a settlement with the U.S. Justice Department.

entry.title: Obama: Racial bias within Ferguson police not isolated
entry.summary: The president made his first remarks about this week's Justice Department report of racial bias in Ferguson, which found officers routinely discriminating against blacks by using excessive force.

entry.title: Michael Brown's family to file civil lawsuit against Ferguson
entry.summary: 'He did not have to kill Michael Brown,' attorney Daryl Parks said of Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson.

entry.title: News24.com | Ferguson policies targeted blacks - attorney
entry.summary: Brown's killing touched off a national debate on race, led to months of street protests and amplified long-standing complaints in Ferguson and across the country of police harassment and mistreatment of minorities.

entry.title: US Justice Department finds racist, profit-driven law enforcement practices in Ferguson
entry.summary:
At the very least, experts said Thursday, Ferguson must move quickly, and publicly, to prove it is serious about regaining public trust.

Most of Ferguson's police officers and city leaders are white, but two-thirds of the 21,000 residents are black.

entry.title: US clears officer in Ferguson case, criticizes police force
Ferguson police employee fired for racially charged e-mails
entry.summary: "Let me be clear, this type of behavior will not be tolerated in the Ferguson Police Department or in any department in the city of Ferguson," said Knowles.

entry.title: Ferguson police employee fired, 2 others on leave over racist emails found in federal probe
entry.summary:
- Ferguson Mayor James Knowles says one police department employee was fired and two others are on administrative leave over racist emails uncovered in a Justice Department investigation into the city's law enforcement practices.

Knowles' comments at a press conference Wednesday were the first response from city leaders to the federal investigation that found systemic racial bias in law enforcement in the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson.

entry.title: Ferguson employee fired, 2 others on leave over emails
Will Ferguson change after scathing federal report?
entry.summary: With scathing findings of a months-long investigation being released, attention now turns to Ferguson as the city confronts how to fix racial biases that the federal government says are deeply rooted in the police department, court and jail.

entry.title: US clears officer in Ferguson case, criticizes police force
entry.summary: A separate report said blacks in Ferguson are disproportionately subject to excessive police force, baseless traffic stops and citations for infractions as petty as walking down the middle of the street.

entry.title: U.S. Justice Department finds racial bias in Ferguson police practices
entry.summary: Civil rights attorney Jerryl Christmas, who has represented people who have clashed with Ferguson police and city officials, said he was not surprised by the findings, and he hopes to see Ferguson Police Chief Tom Jackson fired.

entry.title: Racist Obama joke revealed in scathing Justice Department report on 'biased' Ferguson police practices
entry.summary: The U.S. Justice Department has concluded that the Ferguson, Missouri, police department routinely engages in racially biased practices, a law enforcement official familiar with the department's findings said on Tuesday.

entry.title: U.S. justice department set to Ferguson police display sweeping patters of discrimination: report
entry.summary: WASHINGTON - A U.S. Justice Department investigation will allege sweeping patterns of discrimination within the Ferguson, Missouri, police department and at the municipal jail and court, a law enforcement official familiar with the report said Tuesday.

entry.title: U.S. Justice Department finds racial bias in Ferguson police practices
entry.summary: The investigation into the police department began in August after the shooting of unarmed African-American teen Michael Brown by a white police officer in Ferguson sparked national protests.

entry.title: Ferguson officials to meet with Justice Department
entry.summary: Overall, African-Americans make up 67 percent of the population of Ferguson, about 10 miles north of downtown St. Louis.

entry.title: Upcoming DOJ Ferguson Findings Likely To Reveal No Criminal Charges For Darren Wilson
entry.summary: Along with the police chokehold death of a New York City man suspected of selling untaxed cigarettes and the December killings of two New York police officers, the Ferguson case became part of a national conversation about race and policing.

entry.title: Ferguson News Guide: No charges expected for policeman
entry.summary:

WASHINGTON (AP) - The federal investigation of the police shooting in Ferguson, Missouri, is expected to allege patterns of racial bias in the city's mostly white department.

entry.title: Report to criticize Ferguson police for discriminatory practices
entry.summary: Either way, the result is likely to be significant changes inside the Ferguson Police Department, which is at the center of a national debate over race and policing.

entry.title: Justice Dept. examining Ferguson racial discrimination
entry.summary: In August, Ferguson was thrust into the limelight when white police officer Darren Wilson shot and killed unarmed black teen Michael Brown.

entry.title: US 'to sue Ferguson police over charges of racial bias - but not for Darren Wilson'
entry.summary: The outlet said Justice Department officials are, however, planning to sue the Ferguson Police Department for racially discriminatory practices unless the department agrees to make changes.
